inlineContent.text: AdSDK provides powerful functionality for user tagging and conversion tracking. In this tutorial, we will look at this functionality.
We will continue to build the app, so be sure to follow all the previous tutorials. You can download
which has already implemented all steps from this tutorial.

sections.chapter: Working with the built-in capabilities of the SDK
sections.title: User tagging and conversion tracking

inlineContent.text: Let’s create a new
file in
In it, we create a screen where the user will buy the product, displaying the id, price, quantity, and total cost.
Now we return to the
file. First, let’s focus on the
Let’s add a random price for the product and keep the reference to
in the property.
All that remains is to change the
We add a price and a button that will take us to the basket. Now our app is ready to create purchases!

Before considering user tagging and conversion tracking, we need to prepare the application to have appropriate places to perform tagging and tracking. In this section, we will add an option to purchase the product shown in the inline ad.
Let’s continue with the
file. Let’s imagine a situation where we need to tag a user when he adds an item to the basket.
To do this, first of all, we add the
method to the
, and call it when the
opens the
screen.
Now we’re ready to tag the user. You use
to describe the tagging request. It consists of tags with a
, a
, and a
. In our case, we’ll use
as the name of our store,
as the product category, and
as our product id.
In real projects, the advertiser should provide you with information on the tag parameters.
You can perform a user tagging request with
method. Congratulations, now our app can tag the user who added the item to the basket!

The SDK provides functionality to put a user identifier, e.g. cookie id, into a retargeting segment (to tag a user). This allows advertisers to create a segment of users with certain interests or affinities, and to re-advertise to this segment (retargeting). In this section, we will look at how we can perform a tag request using the AdSDK.
Let’s open the
file and focus on the
. The conversion, in our case, is the purchase of an item in the basket.
A conversion tracking request is described using
. In it, we pass all the parameters related to the purchase.
In real projects, the advertiser should provide you with information on the
and
parameters.
Now we can perform the tracking request. We use
for this purpose, and in case of an error, we display it on the screen. Congratulations, our app can now track purchase!

The SDK allows you to track conversions. This is useful for advertisers, as conversion details would be available in posttracking reports via the adserver. In this section, we will look at how we can perform a tracking request using the AdSDK.

sections.title: Global parameters for all request types

abstract.text: We already know how to create and perform

. However, each of them can have additional parameters, which are called global parameters because they are specified globally for all requests. The SDK provides the ability to add global parameters once so that you don’t have to copy them when creating each request.
Sometimes you need to handle taps in your own way. For example, to display ads in the internal browser in the app. In this tutorial, we will learn how to customise the SDK’s tap handling behaviour.

abstract.text: Sometimes you need to handle taps in your own way. For example, to display ads in the internal browser in the app. In this tutorial, we will learn how to customise the SDK’s tap handling behaviour.
Manage, display, and create your custom advertisements on iOS using cutting-edge technologies such as Structured Concurrency, and SwiftUI.
